II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
The  provision  of  urban  infrastructure  services  in  Uzbekistan  has  deteriorated  since
independence  in  1991  due  to  budgetary  constraints.  Operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of
aging  assets  is  becoming  increasingly  difficult  and  the  cost  of  service  delivery  has  risen.  The
Government  recognizes  the  need  for  institutional  change  and  development.  Under  its  reform
policy,  the  Government  has  decentralized  authority  and  responsibility  for  the  operation  and
management  of  urban  infrastructure  assets  to  local  authorities.  The  Asian  Development  Bank
(ADB)  through  its  country  operational  strategy1  seeks  to  assist  Uzbekistan  in  managing  the
transition  to  a  market  economy  and  reduce  poverty  through  institutional  development.
Assistance in the urban sector is aimed at addressing governance and decentralization issues,
particularly in the provision of communal services and management.

3.
In 1999, the Government asked ADB to support the improvement of urban infrastructure
at the local level. ADB approved a TA2 in May 2000 to assist the Government in preparing its
first  urban  infrastructure  project.  The  TA  was  implemented  by  the  Uzbekistan  Communal
Services  Agency  (Uzcommunkhizmat)  (UCSA)3  and  was  completed  in  July  2001.  The  TA
supported  local  capacity  building  and  designed  an  investment  proposal  for  decentralized
development of urban infrastructure in three cities. The TA was divided into three parts. Part A
assessed  the  current  situation  and  proposed  measures  to  strengthen  urban  infrastructure
policies,  including  preparation  of  an  urban  infrastructure  sector  profile.  Part  B  was  the
preparation  of  a  medium-term  urban  infrastructure  investment  program  where  priority  projects
for  the  next  5  to  10  years  were  identified.  After  screening  investment  needs  in  various  urban
subsectors, the highest needs were established for water supply, heating, and hot water. Under
part  C,  the  TA  consultants  helped  the  central  and  local  governments  and  sector  agencies
develop  an  investment  proposal  covering  three  water  supply  and  two  heating  and  hot  water
components  in  three  cities,  and  a  capacity  building  program.  Due  to  insufficient  counterpart
funds  to  cover  all  the  components,  the  Government  decided  to  proceed  with  only  the  water
supply  component,  in  line  with  its  priority  program  for  the  urban  infrastructure  sector.  The
proposed  Project  was  prepared  in  close  consultation  with  the  communities,  and  detailed
analyses,  including  socioeconomic  surveys,  were  carried  out.  A  participatory  approach,
involving  the  communities  and  local  government  agencies,  was  used  to  formulate  the  Project.

Sector Description

1. 

Economy in Transition

4.
Uzbekistan  lies  at  the  heart  of  Central  Asia  and  is  a  double  landlocked  country.  The
territory  comprises  448,000  square  kilometers  with  a  population  of  24.58  million  in  2000  of
which  about  9.2  million  (38  percent)  is  urban.  The  country  has  22  cities  with  Tashkent,  the
country’s  capital,  being  the  largest  with  a  population  of  2.1  million.  The  six  largest  cities  have
populations between 200,000 and 400,000.5

5.
Uzbekistan  has  adopted  its  own  form  of  a  gradualist  reform  strategy  to  minimize  the
social costs of transition. The depth and duration of the postindependence decline in incomes
has  been  less  severe  than  in  other  Commonwealth  of  Independent  States  countries.  Modest
economic  growth  resumed  in  1996.  In  1998  and  1999,  the  economy  suffered  from  three
exogenous  shocks:  the  Russian  Federation’s  financial  crisis;  adverse  weather  conditions  that
affected  the  cotton  harvests;  and  low  international  prices  for  gold  and  cotton,  Uzbekistan’s
principal  exports.  In  1999  and  2000  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  by  4.4  and  4.0
percent.  However,  inflation  is  high,  exceeding  24  percent  in  2000,  and  is  expected  to  remain
high. Interest rates continue to remain negative in real terms and the investment climate has not
improved.  The  external  sector  situation  is  a  cause  of  concern  with  the  external  debt  servicing
burden rising, and the current account continuing to deteriorate. Economic performance in 2001
is  forecast  to  remain  modest  in  2001  with  GDP  growth  at  4.5  percent,  inflation  at  22  percent,
and  the  balance  of  payment  situation  still  under  pressure.  The  agriculture  sector  faces
worsening  prospects  both  on  account  of  recent  adverse  weather  conditions  and  continued
distortion of the incentives structure due to administrative controls and regulations. The industry
sector  may  receive  a  boost  as  a  result  of  the  concessions  announced  for  the  small-  and
medium-size  enterprise  sector  on  22  June  2001.6  These  have  improved  access  of  small-  and
medium-size enterprises to foreign exchange and included some policy changes that will raise
their profitability.

6.

scope of the commercial rate, which is determined by demand and supply of foreign currency.

2. 

Financial Constraints

8.
During  the  Soviet  era,  government-funded  public  organizations  were  responsible  for
providing  urban  infrastructure  services.  Financial  management  was  not  based  on  commercial
principles. While tariffs were in place before independence, they were low and not intended to
cover  the  full  cost  of  service  provision.  Since  1991,  in  line  with  the  Government’s  policy  on
transition to a market economy, institutions responsible for providing public services have been
undergoing  a  transition  to  become  self-financing  organizations.  Institutions  such  as  the
vodokanals  (water  supply  and  sewerage  agencies)  have  been  working  on  a  self-financing
principle  since  the  Soviet  period.  However,  weaknesses  in  collecting  water  charges  and
managing  the  financial  system  mean  that  they  continue  to  remain  dependent  on  budget
allocations  for  any  capacity  upgrading  or  expansion.  Recent  financial  performance  of  public
services  utility  agencies  indicates  that  all  are  suffering  from  acute  financial  constraints  arising
from increasing expenditures due to inflationary pressure and deteriorating assets that require
urgent  maintenance.  Inadequate  delivery  of  urban  infrastructure  services  is  a  direct  result  of
these  financial  constraints.  For  the  water  utilities  in  most  cities,  although  tariffs  have  been
increased for residential, industrial, and government consumers since 1997, collection rates are
low  and  falling,  partly  because  of  the  poor  and  decreasing  standard  of  service.  The  water
utilities  are  all  in  a  difficult  financial  position  and  constrained  by  lack  of  funding  to  expand  or
modernize  their  facilities.  Thus,  these  agencies  need  to  strengthen  their  capacity  to  better
manage their assets, operations, and finances. Governance of these organizations should also
be improved to ensure accountability and transparency of their operation and management. The
utility agencies recognize their weaknesses and are committed to reform.

3. 

Poverty and Social Protection

9.
Poverty  in  Uzbekistan  is  multidimensional  in  character.  Low-income  families  rely  on
strong family support and assistance from the Government. While the incidence and extent of
poverty has worsened since independence due to a decline in income, Government programs
for output stabilization, and expenditure on health, education, and social protection are having a
positive impact. For example, low-income families that are unable to afford payments for basic
needs and services such as food, water, and heating may apply for social protection payments,

Water Supply and Sanitation

13.
The problems of urban water supply exist at the macro and micro levels throughout the
country.  They  may  be  summarized  as  (i)  geographically  restricted  raw  water  resources;  (ii)

systems; (iv) absence of suitable pressure controls and restricted available pressure; (v) limited
metering; (vi) difficulties in maintaining existing pumping equipment and a lack of investment in
replacement  pumps;  (vii)  insufficient  capacity  in  reservoirs  to  respond  to  diurnal  variations  in
demand;  (viii)  old  and  deteriorated  water  distribution  networks;  (ix)  high  degree  of  system
losses,  i.e.,  unaccounted  for  water;  (x)  absence  of  effective  demand  management;  (xi)  public
attitude to water as an inexhaustible and very cheap resource resulting in wastage and low tariff
collection rates; (xii) poor condition of irrigation systems leading to the alternative use of potable
water  for  garden  and  land  watering;  and  (xiii)  poor  quality  of  technical  equipment  in  the
vodokanals.  Many  of  these  problems  relate  to  lack  of  funding.  As  water  is  a  basic  need,  the
Government is giving improvement to the water supply a high priority in its program.

Policy Dialogue

1. 

Institutional Reform and Decentralization of Implementation

29.
Infrastructure  investments  have  traditionally  been  planned  and  financed  by  the  central
Government.  While  current  Government  policies,  decrees,  and  resolutions  reflect  significant
commitment  to  implementing  institutional  and  financial  reforms  in  the  urban  infrastructure
sector,  top-down  approaches  are  still  embedded  at  all  administrative  levels  of  government.  In
particular,  participation  of  local  communities  is  rare.  However,  with  Presidential  Decree  2791
and Resolution 493 (footnote 3), delivery and maintenance of urban infrastructure services has
been devolved to the oblasts and cities. The Project addresses decentralization and governance
issues,  particularly  to  strengthen  the  institutional  and  financial  capacity  of  oblast  and  city
governments  to  carry  out  the  decentralized  functions  of  providing  and  maintaining  local  water
supply services. As a result of ADB policy dialogue with the central and local governments, the
Project will be implemented by the city governments and managed by the central Government in
support  of  the  Government’s  decentralization  policy.  The  Project  and  the  associated  TA  will
provide capacity building, particularly at the local level. The Government recognizes that for the
system  to  be  sustainable,  ownership  and  responsibility  must  be  passed  to  the  users.  The
Project is structured to increase local responsibility for water supply services by decentralizing
implementation  and  O&M,  and  actively  involving  both  government  and  community-based
stakeholders.

Raising  the  Standards  of  Urban  Water  Supply  Service  Delivery  and
Maintenance

30.
Infrastructure  facilities  built  during  the  Soviet  period  were  capital  and  energy  intensive,
and inefficient and expensive to operate and maintain. While the normative standards set for all
urban  water  utility  services  were  high,  capacity  is  increasingly  lagging  behind  expanding
demand  and  there  are  no  incentives  to  conserve  water.  Urgent  improvements  are  required  to

the  water  distribution  systems  across  the  country,  including  strengthening  of  pipe  networks,
supply  zoning  with  flow  and  pressure  controls,  active  leakage  reduction  practices,  and
rehabilitation  and  reequipping  of  pumping  stations.  This  will  contribute  to  meeting  service
standards  and  improving  the  delivery  of  water  in  urban  centers  to  meet  basic  human
development needs. In parallel with these interventions, awareness for conservation of water as
a  valuable  resource  will  be  increased.  This  will  be  achieved  through  education  and  public
awareness  campaigns  in  conjunction  with  improved  customer  services.  Tariff  reforms  and
introduction  of  metering  of  both  bulk  water  supply  and  local  consumption  will  help  raise
awareness and provide incentives for water conservation. The Government views water supply
sector reform as a high priority. Through policy dialogue, the Government supports rehabilitation
of the existing water supply facilities in the three oblast capital cities with the most urgent needs
for urban infrastructure repair and rehabilitation. Delivery of water services when compared with
government standards and of all those surveyed is the poorest in these three cities. Part of the
population  do  not  receive  water  every  day  and  where  water  is  available  daily,  the  supply  is
rationed. Water needs to be stored when it is available, and bottled water is used for those who
can  afford  it.  The  emphasis  will  be  on  rehabilitating  and  upgrading  existing  facilities  by  using
cost-efficient  technology  and  approaches.  Community  participation  in  capital  repairs  and
maintenance  of  major  common  elements  in  apartment  buildings  are  also  important  to  ensure
that  improved  water  services  are  available  to  individual  households.  Fostering  partnerships
between  the  community,  the  utility  agencies,  and  local  governments  will  result  in  more
responsive infrastructure service delivery and maintenance. The Project is therefore structured
to  build  ownership  and  responsibility  at  the  local  level  and  is  aimed  at  improving  customer

3. 

Financial Performance of the Utility Agencies

31.
The  Government  is  in  the  process  of  reforming  utility  agencies  from  budget-run
organizations to self-financing agencies, with the ability to raise and manage their own finance.
Vodokanals are self-financing organizations and do not receive operational subsidies from the
Government.  Expenditure requirements are increasing due to inflation and an increasing need
for O&M expenditure on aging assets. Capital investment is urgently needed to enable systems
to  function  correctly.  Vodokanal  income  is  hampered  by  poor  tariff  collection,  and  despite
increases in tariffs, all vodokanals are suffering from severe financial constraints because actual
income  does  not  cover  inflation  and  increasing  O&M  expenditures.  As  assets  deteriorate,
service standards decline, customers become less willing to pay, and the ability to collect tariffs
worsens. As a result, maintenance and asset replacement is inadequate. This compounds the
downward  spiral  and  negates  financial  self-sustainability.  Furthermore,  utility  agencies  are
unable to properly manage their finances using internationally accepted accounting standards.

32.
Through  policy  dialogue,  the  Government  agreed  to  improve  service  delivery  by  these
agencies;  restructure  tariffs  to  introduce  charging  by  volume  for  residential,  as  well  as
commercial  and  industrial  customers;  help  those  on  lower  incomes;  improve  education  and
awareness;  provide  a  transparent  billing  and  collection  system;  and  improve  the  financial
management system. All these factors will improve collection of tariffs. In addition, tariffs will be
increased. In line with Government policies to decentralize and reform the provision and delivery
of basic urban services, the Project will assist in improving governance including operation and
financial management of water utility agencies to ensure that their transformation is sustainable.

agrees  that  (i)  full  cost  recovery  should  be  targeted  for  all  project  components;  (ii)  in  the  long
term, cross-subsidies should be minimized, but if affordability criteria cannot be met, then cross-
subsidization should be pursued; (iii) the use of stepped tariffs for water, with lower rates for low
volume use, is a useful approach in assisting those on lower incomes; (iv) where affordability is
low,  differential  pricing  can  assist  in  cost  recovery  and  improve  collection  rates;  and  (v)  tariffs
should  be  reviewed  annually  to  take  into  account  collection  rates,  expenditure,  and  future
investment plans; tariffs should be adjusted accordingly.

Experience  indicates  that  beneficiary  participation,  good  governance,  and  project

addresses site-specific needs and constraints. Consumer participation in training and decision-

35. While  poverty  reduction  is  not  an  explicit  government  policy,  the  Government  has

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

38.
Since independence in 1991, budgetary support for urban infrastructure has slowed and
water supply infrastructure assets deteriorated. As a result, the urban population, including the
poor, receives inferior and intermittent water utility services. Since urban water supply plays a
vital  role  in  determining  the  living  standards  and  pattern  of  human  development,  the
deterioration of the water supply system must be stopped and strategies introduced to ensure
that  acceptable  standards  are  attained  at  costs  that  will  not  adversely  affect  the  population,
particularly the poor. As part of the reform process, the Government is decentralizing authority
and  responsibility  for  urban  infrastructure  and  devolving  its  assets  to  local  authorities.

 13

Simultaneously, the Government recognizes the need to set tariffs for utilities and services at a
level  that  will  ensure  the  services  can  be  sustained.  However,  increased  charges  and  tariffs,
while necessary for sustainability, might not be affordable to the financially disadvantaged, and
project  interventions  must  strike  a  balance  between  resource  pricing  and  poverty  reduction
considerations.  To  this  end,  mechanisms  necessary  to  protect  vulnerable  sections  of  the
community against unaffordable cost increases are included in the project design.

39.
Based on an assessment of performance data of each urban infrastructure subsector in
22  cities  throughout  the  country,  potable  water  supply  in  Djizzak,  Gulistan,  and  Karshi  were
identified as having the most urgent need for rehabilitation and upgrading. Water supply in the
three  cities  is  characterized  by  limited  availability  of  raw  water  resources  and  lack  of
conservation awareness and responsibility. Unaccounted for water is around 40 percent in the
three  cities.  Underfunding  of  assets  for  a  significant  period  has  led  to  antiquated  equipment,
inefficiency,  and  equipment  failures.  Currently  only  about  60  percent  of  the  population  in  the
three  project  cities  receive  some  water  every  day.  If  the  water  systems  are  not  upgraded,
Djizzak and Karshi will likely fail to supply the basic water requirement by 2007 and the system
will fail totally by 2015. The Gulistan system is in worse condition and will fail totally within five
years if the system is not upgraded or rehabilitated. Sewerage was not included in the Project
as the existing wastewater treatment facilities in the three project cities have sufficient capacity
to treat the additional water consumption, which is not expected to increase substantially, as a
result of improving the water system (para. 16).

40.
Management  problems  include  inability  of  the  water  utility  agencies  to  manage  the
assets in a modern and effective manner; this is further hindered by limited financial resources,
restricted  technological  expertise,  and  absence  of  economic  incentives.  The  Project  seeks  to
address  each  of  these  problems  by  creating  a  modern  and  efficient  operation  from  which  the
whole  population  can  expect  an  acceptable  standard  of  service  at  an  affordable  cost.  The
Project will support the Government’s policy to decentralize urban infrastructure services to local
governments  and  to  transform  the  utility  agencies  into  financially  independent  entities.  To
ensure  long-term  sustainability  of  the  sector,  the  Project  has  adopted  a  holistic  approach  to
improve  the  institutional,  technical,  and  financial  capacity  of  the  concerned  agencies.  The
Project seeks to make major improvements in asset performance, and to establish capacity for
serving  the  population  over  the  planning  period  to  2020.  The  Project  will  strengthen  and
upgrade the quality and availability of water supply to the population in the three project cities
and  will  improve  the  quality  of  life  of  both  the  poor  and  nonpoor.  The  Project  is  in  line  with
Government’s  decentralization  of  communal  services  and  institutional  reform  policies,  and
ADB’s human development and poverty reduction objectives.

population  are  poor,18  by  improving  basic  water  supply  services.  The  Project  will  (i)  assist  the
central  and  local  governments  and  the  utility  agencies  with  upgrading  the  physical  delivery
systems for potable water supply; (ii) improve the institutional, technical, and financial capability
of  local  governments  and  vodokanals  for  planning,  implementation,  and  O&M  of  the  facilities;

C. 

Technical Justification

Each  of  the  three  project  cities  has  a  centralized  water  supply  system  that  is  suffering
47.
from production deficiencies and a fragile distribution network, both unable to sustain necessary
delivery  pressures  and  lagging  behind  expansion  of  the  city  and  growth  of  its  population.  The
results are insufficient capacity, inefficient operation, and poor water quality. The Project will use
appropriate technology to improve borehole resources and system storage; develop reticulated
systems and strengthen distribution networks; renew pumping equipment and supply mains to
increase delivery pressure; provide disinfection facilities to protect against waterborne diseases;
and reduce leakage from the distribution network by zoning, metering, and repair. Unaccounted
for water will be targeted for reduction from the present level (city vodokanals report it to be in
excess of 40 percent), to approximately 30 percent by project completion. An improved system
and  more  secure  water  supply  to  areas  both  currently  served  and  without  an  existing  piped
supply  will  ensure  improvements  to  the  health  and  general  welfare  of  the  population.  By
reducing water supply  losses  and  extravagant use, as water is charged per capita and not by
volume consumed, the existing inefficiencies and resulting costs can be minimized. Security of
supply  and  improved  standard  of  service  will  increase  the  willingness  to  pay  for  service  and
improve cost recovery. Total demand for water may increase in the future due to (i) expanded
coverage of the supply network from currently over 90 percent to 100 percent of the population
by  2007,  (ii)  delivery  of  24-hour  water  supply,  (iii)  natural  population  growth,  and  (iv)
improvements in the standard of living. Total demand for the three cities is projected to increase
from the current 46,000 m3/day to 80,000 m3/day in 2020 for Djizzak, 45,000 m3/day to 60,000
m3/day for Gulistan, and 110,000 m3/day to 130,000 m3/day in Karshi. However, required water
production per capita is expected to drop over time as a result of increased appreciation of the
value  of  water  developed  by  public  awareness  campaigns,  improved  efficiencies  within  the
delivery network, development of techniques of accounting for water, and freedom of choice on
consumption provided by metering and tariff policies that promote water conservation.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Economic and Financial Analyses

1. 

Economic Analysis

83.
Urban  water  supply  services  in  the  project  cities  are  inadequate.  Assets  have
deteriorated and lack of maintenance is such that service delivery of water is severely affected.
Without major investment in the near future the central water supply will continue to deteriorate
rapidly,  with  serious  consequences  for  economic  activity  and  livelihood.  Currently,  water
rationing  occurs  in  all  three  cities.    Water  shortages,  cuts,  and  pressure  problems  mean  that
only about 60 percent of the population receive some water every day. Without the Project, by
2007, the water supply system in Djizzak and Karshi will probably fail to supply even basic water
requirements  and  30  percent  of  the  population  will  not  have  access  to  a  piped  water  supply.
This proportion of households without access to a piped water supply is expected to gradually
increase,  until  the  system  totally  fails,  which  is  expected  within  15  years.  In  Gulistan,  the
situation is even more severe, where without the Project, by 2007, 100 percent of households
will  be  without  access  to  a  piped  water  supply,  since  total  failure  of  the  system  is  expected
within five years. The Project is considered high priority by the Government, is timely, and well
integrated with other investment activity. The Project will benefit about 484,000 residential water
supply  customers,  industries,  small  businesses,  and  other  organizations  in  the  three  cities.
Access to a clean, safe, and reliable water supply system will benefit poor and nonpoor alike as
they  are  not  geographically  separated  and  all  households  will  have  access  to  the  improved
system.

84.
The  water  supply  components  will  (i)  generate  major  efficiency  gains,  reducing
distribution  leakage,  and  water  and  electricity  costs;  (ii)  improve  cost  recovery  through  better
customer satisfaction with service delivery; (iii) reduce natural resource depletion; (iv) improve
public  health  by  reducing  the  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases;  and  (v)  support  economic

 27

recovery.  Unaccounted for water will be reduced from an estimated more than 40 percent, to a
target of 30 percent in 2007.

85.
An  analysis  of  alternatives  was  undertaken.  Djizzak  has  no  alternative  water  source  in
the short to medium term; the only alternative water source from the Zarafshan river scheme will
not be available within the time frame of this Project. In Gulistan, two specific alternatives were
considered,  including  total  reliance  on  the  borehole  field  at  Dehkanabad  (under  the
responsibility of UCSA) and total reliance on borehole fields under the responsibility of the city
vodokanal.  However,  both  alternatives  are  about  10  percent  more  expensive  and  the  chosen
scheme is more acceptable in terms of implementation. In Karshi, the unit costs of the chosen
scheme  were  about  10  percent  cheaper  than  the  next  best  alternative.  The  consideration  of
alternative  sources  was  strengthened  by  the  choice  of  the  most  cost-effective  rehabilitation  of
the distribution system. Only items that were considered essential for establishing a sustainable
system were included in the project design.

86.
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculation was undertaken in constant 2001
prices  using  the  domestic  price  numeraire,  since  the  outputs  are  nontradable  in  nature.
Economic costs, excluding taxes and financial prices, are converted using factors of (i) 2.0 for
the  shadow  exchange  rate  factor  (SERF)  and  (ii)  0.8  for  labor.  Nonincremental  economic
benefits that were valued include (i) use of bottled water, (ii) time savings for water collection,
(iii)  industrial  resource  cost  savings,  and  (iv)  savings  of  health  expenditure.  Incremental
economic benefits that were valued include (i) residential willingness to pay, and (ii) increases in
small business output.

The  EIRR  is  18.2  percent  in  Djizzak,  17.2  percent  in  Gulistan,  and  24.4  percent  in
87.
Karshi.  For the three cities the EIRR exceeds the economic opportunity cost of capital, which is
assumed to be 12 percent. Standard sensitivity tests were undertaken to consider the impact of
economic  risks,  encompassed  in  adverse  cost  and  benefit  scenarios  and  delays  in  benefits.
Since  the  economic  risk  is  considered  to  be  higher  than  for  standard  ADB  projects,  the
sensitivity tests were set at 20 percent. In addition, for each city, project-specific sensitivity tests
were  undertaken.  These  include  (i)  a  higher  SERF,  equivalent  to  the  use  of  the  market
exchange  rate,  (ii)  increases  in  key  O&M  costs,  and  (iii)  decreases  in  demand  for  bottled
water—the  most  sensitive  valued  benefit.  Under  all  the  sensitivity  tests,  the  components  were
found to be economically viable. Sensitivity indicators and switching values were calculated for
standard sensitivity tests and for the SERF. The SERF would need to exceed 4.0, for the EIRR
to fall below the economic opportunity cost of capital. A summary of the economic analysis is in
Appendix 14.

3. 

Affordability Analysis and Project Sustainability

92.
As  discussed  in  para.  73,  full  cost  recovery  from  user  charges  is  targeted  for  all  three
cities to ensure project sustainability and operation of the utility agencies. At the same time, the
poor must be protected from the increase in charges. Current tariff is based on a flat per capita
charge irrespective of the volume of water consumed. The proposed tariff structure will charge
customers  by  volume  of  water  used  and  a  lifeline  tariff  is  proposed  for  low  consumption
households. An affordability analysis has been undertaken to assess whether the proposed tariff
is  affordable  to  residential  consumers,  based  on  estimated  tariffs  and  household  income  data
from the social survey. Since a single tariff is neither appropriate nor affordable, a tariff structure
has  been  prepared  for  each  city,  based  on  the  assessment  of  average  required  tariff  and  the
demand for water use by customer type. The proposed structure includes a lifeline tariff set at
75 lcd, a tariff for consumption between 75 lcd and 125 lcd, and a higher tariff for consumption
over 125 lcd. Different tariffs will be charged for residential and nonresidential consumers.

Average  household  charges  were  compared  with  willingness-to-pay.  Results  from  the
93.

month  for  water.  Proposed  charges  for  average  water  consumption  ranging  from  SUM687  to
SUM957 per household are below the average willingness-to-pay.

94.
Proposed  average  household  charges  were  also  compared  with  average  household
income. Water charges for less than 5 percent of income are considered to be affordable, in line
with ADB affordability criteria. Proposed charges are 4 percent of household income in Djizzak,
5 percent in Gulistan, and 4 percent in Karshi. For very low-income residents, proposed charges
for 75 lcd were compared with the income of the poorest 10 percent of households. Proposed
charges  are  lower  than  5  percent  of  household  income  in  the  three  project  cities.  Detailed
affordability analysis is in Appendix 16.

Gender and Development

The  Project  will  benefit  women  as  they  are  traditionally  responsible  for  cooking  and

wastes and effluents, and from solid waste disposal in landfills. However, the three project cities

Background

2. 
Uzbekistan’s population was estimated at 24.6 million in 2000 and is forecast to grow to
28 million by 2010. Official projections show that the urban population will increase by 1 million
over the next 10 years to reach 10.2 million. The national population structure is relatively young
with  around  41  percent  of  persons  under  15  years  of  age  and  4  percent  above  60  (1988

challenge to the Government in future years. The incidence and extent of poverty has worsened
since  independence.  Per  capita  income  fell  by  approximately  24  percent  between  1991  and

particularly  in  the  public  sector  where  wages  have  not  kept  pace  with  inflation.  Low-income
families  rely  on  strong  family  support  and  on  the  mahalla  benefits  system.  This  system  of
neighborhood committees provides the basis for the administration of the Government’s social
welfare  support  system.  Mahalla  officials  screen  families  according  to  officially  defined  criteria
and  administer  welfare  payments  to  those  who  are  most  in  need.  On  health,  Uzbekistan
inherited  an  outdated  health  system  from  Soviet  times,  and  although  significant  progress  has
been  made  since  1991,  health  facilities  need  to  be  improved  to  meet  the  pressing  needs  of  a
growing  population.  On  education,  Uzbekistan  had  97  percent  literacy  and  an  average  of  10

maintenance.

3.

dwellings,  schools,  clinics,  and  small  businesses.  Public  dissatisfaction  with  poorly  maintained

4.

in  Djizzak  households  in  hovles  averaged  5.42  persons  and  in  apartments  3.35  persons.  In

When poverty is measured in terms of quality of life, such as vulnerability to water cuts
and other service deficiencies, then the majority of the urban population is exposed to varying
degrees.  Only  29  percent  of  respondents  expressed  no  water  supply  problems.  While  poor

capacities of apartment dwellers are less than that of those living in hovles. Households headed
by women are more likely to live in apartments; extended family structures in hovles more often
have adult males who can generate income either on a formal or casual basis.

6. 
The  key  issue  is  whether  households  can  afford  to  pay  for  alternatives  to  mitigate  the
effects of service deficiencies. Higher income families can minimize the amount of time spent on
collecting water by purchasing water pumps and storage tanks or paying for trucked delivery of
water.  Low-income  families,  in  particular  women,  cope  by  carrying  buckets  of  water  several
times per day to their homes and often have to climb stairs when elevators are not functioning
or working. In households headed by low-income elderly, sick, or disabled people, vulnerability
is highest as they cannot carry heavy buckets and need to carry small amounts more frequently.

Small businesses such as restaurants, hair salons, and other personal services reported
that  their  turnover  is  highly  sensitive  to  water  supply  problems.  Schools  are  extremely
vulnerable to service deficiencies. Lack of water severely affects hygiene leading to waterborne
diseases  and  hepatitis  outbreaks.  Many  low-income  households  cannot  afford  medical
treatment.  Clinics  are  unable  to  maintain  standards  of  hygiene  due  to  deficient  supply  of  safe
water.

D. 

Role of Women

8. 
Women  are  affected  most  by  water  supply  and  other  service  problems,  since  they  are
primarily  responsible  for  cooking,  cleaning,  child  care,  and  taking  care  of  the  sick  and  elderly.
The high incidence of deficiencies in the drinking water systems in the project cities mean that
women have to develop coping mechanisms to fulfil their traditional roles. Women in low-income
families are particularly vulnerable to service deficiencies as they have less money to purchase
alternatives  such  as  bottled  water.  The  majority  of  teachers  in  the  three  project  cities  are
women, who reported that schools are particularly affected by water supply deficiencies. Water
often  has  to  be  collected  and  stored  during  lesson  times  so  that  at  meal  times  drinking  water
supplies and general hygiene can be maintained.

E. 

Water Sources and Availability

9. 
Water  pressure  is  the  most  common  problem  where  water  cannot  reach  the  taps  in
houses and apartments. Households above the second floor in apartments and also hovles on
high ground are most severely affected. Other problems include daily scheduled water cuts and
frequent  unscheduled  water  cuts,  often  for  two  to  three  days.  In  these  conditions,  households
and  small  businesses  have  difficulty  maintaining  hygienic  practices.  Recent  medical  research
carried out by the Ministry of Health demonstrated the link between the incidence of typhoid and
low  pressure  in  water  pipes  (and  consequent  reflux),  water  losses  through  taps  and  leaking
pipes. All these conditions exist in the three project cities.

10.  Many households living in apartments (62 percent in Djizzak, 47 percent in Gulistan, and
23 percent in Karshi) said that they do not receive water from existing taps or standpipes inside
their  homes.  A  smaller  proportion  of  households  living  in  hovles  (31  percent  in  Karshi,  18
percent Gulistan, and 11 percent in Djizzak) also indicated they do not receive water from taps
or standpipes within their homes or gardens. Household members (mainly women) have to find
other sources such as standpipes in the street, from residents living at lower levels in apartment
blocks  and  from  residents  living  in  low-level  hovles.  All  these  sources  are  also  subject  to
pressure  problems  and  therefore  not  constantly  available.  In  some  cases  local  factories  with
their own boreholes and pumps sell water to households. In Karshi where some of the outlying
mahallas have no water pipes, water is sometimes collected directly from boreholes or supplied
by water tankers to those who can afford it.

Community Structures and Social Support System

11. 
The  project  cities  are  divided  into  neighborhood  communities  administered  by  mahalla
committees and headed by an aksakal  (chief elder). The mahalla system is a traditional Islamic
community-based  organization,  which  has  been  further  developed  by  the  Government  and  is
now organized into a hierarchy of committees at the oblast (region) and national levels. One of
the  key  responsibilities  of  the  mahalla  committees  is  to  administer  the  social  welfare  system
whereby low-income families can receive financial support (from which tariffs may be paid). The
system tends to favor large families and elderly living alone and not all applicants from smaller
households  are  able  to  obtain  assistance.  During  focus  group  discussions  some  respondents
said that inflation had reduced the value of their subsidies.

12. 
Social  organization  and  group  formation  is  higher  among  hovle  dwellers  as  they  are
more likely to be Uzbeks and involved in mahalla activities. A small number of nongovernment
organization activities are associated with the mahallas. Residents in apartment blocks have a
variety of ethnicity and comparatively less control over routine repairs to pipes. Some apartment
blocks  have  formed  housing  partnerships  to  improve  their  conditions.  These  housing
partnerships, which have the right to decide on building repair matters, have the potential to be
used  as  a  basis  for  social  awareness  projects.  The  city  governments  also  have  women’s
committees who are responsible for women’s development and welfare issues in the cities. The
level of activity of these committees varies.

Apartment dwellers are particularly vulnerable in that most of them are not in control of getting

POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

Uzbekistan has no agreed or reliable measure of poverty and no official poverty line. The
1. 
average per capita monthly income in 2000 was estimated at SUM6,480.1 Since independence
income  distribution  has  worsened  between  income  groups,  sectors,  and  regions.  The  national
Gini  coefficient  grew  from  0.26  in  1991  to  0.42  in  1998.2  In  Government  terms  the  poor  are
classified as a vulnerable and low-income group based on the prevailing official minimum wage,
which is adjusted regularly for inflation, and in January 2001 was set at SUM2,450 per month.

2. 
The  Government  household  survey  is  the  main  source  for  monitoring  living  standards.
Based  on  the  poverty  line  definition  of  75  roubles  per  capita  per  month  before  independence,
the incidence of poverty, at that time, was estimated to be 44 percent of the working population.
If this measure is updated for the latest household survey (1996)3 to SUM740 per capita then
the  incidence  of  poverty  in  1996  was  21.1percent.  More  recent  work  by  Gesellschaft  für
Technische  Zusammenarbeit,  Tacis,  and  the  World  Bank  in  Tashkent,  Ferghana,  and
Karakalpakstan,  using  the  minimum  wage  criteria,  indicates  that  urban  poverty  in  these  areas
was estimated at 10, 28, and 50 percent, respectively. In the same survey, self-ranked poverty
(i.e.,  not  having  enough  money  for  food  and  medicines)  in  these  areas  ranged  from  30  to  70
percent of the population depending on the location. Using the World Bank definition of poverty
of $1 per day, even at the official exchange rate, would put the average income in Uzbekistan at
approximately two thirds of the $1 a day level. This indicates that the majority of the population
is  poor.  In  1996  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)4  estimated  the  poverty
line based on a basket of goods for the lowest 10 percent of income groups to be SUM1,006 per
capita, or an equivalent of SUM6,011 in 2001 prices.

C.

Approach to Poverty Impact Analysis

4. 
Despite  the  problems  of  establishing  an  agreed  poverty  line,  absolute  poverty  was
assessed to estimate the proportion of poor and nonpoor beneficiaries. The problems involved
in defining a poverty line include (i) use of official statistics that are not always reliable; (ii) use of
narrow definitions of poverty, which tend to ignore the economic, cultural, and social situation in
the  project  area  and  the  difficulties  of  measuring  nonmonetary  benefits;  and  (iii)  unregistered
income, which may form a significant part of actual income levels. Based on this evidence and
in  the  absence  of  an  agreed  Government  definition  of  poverty,  an  estimated  poverty  line  of
SUM4,000  per  capita  per  month  based  on  income,  expenditure,  and  quality  of  life  criteria  has
been  used  to  calculate  the  percentage  of  poor  beneficiaries.  This  is  slightly  lower  than  the
average between the Government minimum wage and the UNDP definition of the poverty line,
and is supported by data on quality of life from the household survey.

D.

Loan Classification

Based on a poverty line of SUM4,000 per capita per month and the social survey results,
5. 
45 percent of project beneficiaries are poor. This includes 37 percent in Djizzak, 44 percent in
Gulistan,  and  51  percent  in  Karshi.  The  loan  is  therefore  classified  as  a  poverty  intervention
since the proportion of beneficiaries classified as poor is in the range of 25 to 50 percent.

E.

Poverty Impact Assessment

6. 
The assessment of poverty impact used for this Project has considered (i) the extent to
which  the  project  targets  areas  where  the  poor  are  located;  (ii)  the  proportion  of  project
beneficiaries  who  are  poor;  (iii)  the  targeting  of  the  project  loan  toward  the  poor;  and  (iv)  the
impact on the quality of life of the poor.

Identification  of  the  poor  within  a  set  of  project  beneficiaries  is  not  possible  for  this
7. 
Project. Poor people live in houses and apartments, and are not geographically clustered within
the  cities.  Since  the  poor  are  not  geographically  clustered,  and  the  Project  covers  the  entire
three  cities,  the  loan  is  not  targeted  more  to  the  poor  than  the  nonpoor.  All  beneficiaries  will
benefit from the improvements to the water supply services.

8. 
Using  a  poverty  line  of  SUM4,000  per  capita  per  month,  the  proportion  of  poor
households  in  the  three  project  cities  is  around  45  percent.  About  45  percent  of  the  Project’s
beneficiaries will be poor. The Project will improve the water supply service to all beneficiaries
whether poor or not. The only difference between poor and nonpoor is that the poor are least
likely to be able to cope under the existing situation as they cannot afford to pay for alternatives.
This situation will worsen if the Project does not go ahead as infrastructure facilities continue to
deteriorate and the service becomes increasingly intermittent or fails completely.

9. 
The  project  loan  from  ADB  provides  55  percent  of  the  project  costs.  The  funds  will  be
targeted at project beneficiaries, 45 percent of whom are poor. Based on this, $16.2 million of
the funds will be targeted to the poor and gives a category B rating for loan targeting.

10. 
Poverty  impact  is  also  measured  in  terms  of  quality  of  life  related  to  a  definition  of  an
acceptable urban living standard including access to basic services such as water supply, all of
which are included in the ADB objective of poverty reduction. For this Project it is assumed that
the  acceptable  urban  living  standard  is  assumed  to  be  the  standard  of  service  provision  that
existed  when  the  water  services  functioned  properly.  The  effects  of  deficiencies  in  present

standards of service delivery are also taken into account. Relative deprivation, which takes into
account  the  urban  lifestyle,  can  also  be  adapted  to  the  specific  quality  of  life  problems
experienced in transitional economies.

Quality  of  life  measures  for  households  appropriate  for  the  water  supply  component  of
11. 
this  Project  include  (i)  access  to  safe  drinking  water,  (ii)  access  to  washing  facilities,  (iii)
morbidity level due to exposure to waterborne disease, and (iv) proportion of the day spent in
water collection (i.e., loss of productive time).

12. 
Area targeting of low-income households is not achievable in the context of Uzbekistan.
However, while middle and higher income households are able to purchase alternative services,
e.g.,  large  water  storage  containers  and  water  pumps,  lower  income  households  are  more
vulnerable to service deficiencies as these coping mechanisms are unaffordable. This leads to
opportunity  costs,  which  have  long-term  implications  and  perpetuate  the  poverty  cycle.  These
families  are  more  vulnerable  to  sickness  and  are  likely  to  spend  a  larger  proportion  of  their
income on medical treatment. This sickness can lead to comparatively low school attendance,
and decreased ability to learn or to be involved in productive work.

13. 
The Project will also provide opportunities for women to use their time more productively
(since they will not have to spend a large amount of time carrying water). Small- and medium-
sized businesses are likely to improve productivity with continuous supply of water. The Project
will  also  create  construction  job  opportunities  for  both  skilled  and  unskilled  labor  during  the
implementation stage. The Project will create about 2,100 person-months of skilled employment
and about 5,000 person-months of unskilled employment.

F.

Conclusion

14. 
Based  on  the  45  percent  poor  beneficiaries,  about  $16.2  million  of  the  loan  will  be
targeted to the poor. The quality of life of the poor will improve as lower income households are
more vulnerable to service deficiencies. The Project will reduce the effect of opportunity costs,
which perpetuate the poverty cycle.
